Database Connections

connections.Rmd

Prerequisites

Before using pifsc.odbc you need to complete two one-time setup steps: installing the Oracle ODBC driver and storing your database credentials.

You must also be connected to the PIFSC network or the NOAA VPN for all database connections.

1. Install Oracle Instant Client

The package requires an Oracle ODBC driver to communicate with the database. Download and install Oracle Instant Client (version 23.9 or later) for your operating system. Make sure to include the ODBC component during installation. After installation, verify the driver is available:

odbc::odbcListDrivers()

You should see an entry named Oracle in instantclient_23_9 (or similar). If the driver name differs on your machine, you can pass your driver name to create_connection() via the driver argument.

2. Store database credentials

pifsc.odbc uses the keyring package to securely store your Oracle username and password in your operating system’s credential manager. This only needs to be done once per machine — credentials persist across R sessions.

Run the following in an interactive R session:

library(pifsc.odbc)
setup_credentials()

You will be prompted to enter your username and password. These are stored under the service names PIFSC_Logbook_user and PIFSC_Logbook_pwd by default.

If you prefer different service names (e.g., to manage credentials for multiple databases), you can specify them during setup:

setup_credentials(uid_service = "MY_DB_user", pwd_service = "MY_DB_pwd")

You will then need to pass the same service names when creating a connection:

con <- create_connection(uid_service = "MY_DB_user", pwd_service = "MY_DB_pwd")

Opening a connection

Once the prerequisites are in place, connecting to the logbook database is straightforward:

library(pifsc.odbc)

con <- create_connection()

This returns a standard DBI connection object. You can use it with any DBI-compatible function:

# List available tables
DBI::dbListTables(con)

# Run a query
result <- DBI::dbGetQuery(con, "SELECT * FROM llds.SOME_TABLE WHERE ROWNUM <= 10")

Custom connection parameters

If you need to connect to a different database or use non-default settings, all parameters can be overridden:

con <- create_connection(
  host = "other-db.nmfs.local",
  port = 1521,
  sid = "other.service.name",
  driver = "Oracle in instantclient_21_3",
  timeout = 30
)

Closing a connection

Always close your connection when finished. Use safe_disconnect() for error-tolerant cleanup, which is especially useful in scripts and parallel workers:

safe_disconnect(con)

Or use the standard DBI approach:

DBI::dbDisconnect(con)
